**The Wondrous Scripture of the Five Talismans of the Supreme Mystery of the Numinous Treasure, Scroll the Middle**

**The Numinous Treasure’s Ingestion of the Essence of the Five Fungi**

The Venerable Lord said: The pine lives a thousand years; its resin congeals to commune with the spirits. Descending into the earth, it conceals its lineage and alters its name, forsaking its origin to grow vast. From its root it takes form, called *Weixi* (威僖), also known as *fuling* (茯苓). It repels weapons and submerges armies, emerging from the profound and entering the obscure. Neither hungering nor thirsting, it unites sun and moon. If one can ingest it, one attains long life.

The Venerable Lord said: The flea nourishes the body, restoring youthful complexion and reversing age. It is called *huma* (胡麻), originally growing in Dawan. Born ten thousand years ago, it came east across the passes, remaining in the Central Land to sever the Hu and barbarian tribes. It embodies the essence of water, dispelling wind and cold. Known also as *jusheng* (巨胜), it expels evil and treachery. Ingesting it without cease, one endures with the world.

*Jusheng* and *Weixi* form kinship, emerging from the Hu lands. They harmonize spirit and essence. If one can ingest them, one thus attains long life.

The Venerable Lord said: Pepper grows in Shu and Han, containing the *qi* of the Great Yin. Born with heaven and earth, it transforms and submerges. Thus it dispels dampness; evil dares not encroach. It devours demonic poisons, none it cannot restrain. If one can ingest it constantly, all desires are sated. This is the world’s arcane mystery, its Dao profound. Guard it firmly, do not reveal it—not for ten thousand gold.

The Venerable Lord said: Ginger grows in the Great Yang, sharing its homeland with pepper. Both emerge from fertile soil, nestled in the secluded mountains. Firm and unyielding, they rely on springs and water. Containing the *qi* of Mars, they guard the earth’s root, turning from yin toward yang, enduring with the world. Thus they dispel dampness, repel cold for warmth, expel evil and sever illness, sealing the demonic gate. If one can ingest them constantly, one’s lifespan matches heaven and earth.

The Venerable Lord said: Sweetflag grows in marshes, near deep pools. In low, damp places—by riverbanks and water’s edge—it also thrives on high mountains, rooting in stone. Nine nodes in an inch: this is called the numinous body. Obtaining even one, it contains the *qi* of ten thousand. Thus it revives people, preserves and nourishes the spirit, dispels water and dampness, suppresses demons and dissolves misfortune. Ghosts, specters, *wangliang*, and baleful spirits flee into dark obscurity; inauspicious omens dare not approach. Ingesting it without cease, one’s lifespan reaches a thousand thousand years.

Master Le Zichang said: These five substances may all be ingested singly. Together, they augment *qi*, preserve youth, extend essence, and stabilize the *po*. Ingesting them without cease, one endures with the world. Thus the *Xiao Jing Yuan Shen Qi* states: Ginger and pepper augment *qi*; sweetflag sharpens hearing; *jusheng* extends years; *Weixi* repels weapons. These are the secret words of Confucius, the luminous decree of the supreme sages.

The Venerable Lord observed heaven and composed the *Five Fungi Elixir*, a method to preserve spirit, sustain years, and endure with the world.

**Numinous Elixir of the Three Heavens Formula**
Recorded by Le Zichang.

**Fivefold Numinous Elixir Formula**

Five parts *jusheng*, four parts *Weixi*, one part Sichuan pepper, three parts dried ginger, and three parts sweetflag. Select only genuine, fresh, and fine specimens, meticulously preparing each. On a day of celestial dominance, have a male virgin grind the ingredients—do not change the person. Process each separately, sift finely, and pound each ten thousand times. Place each in a separate red cup, arranging all five upon a red table, exposed to the open air for one night. At dawn the next day, measure them with the sacred dipper and combine according to method. Blend with white honey or maltose, then pound again thirty thousand times, forming pills the size of parasol seeds. At dawn, face the sun and kneel to swallow three pills, declaring your wish for longevity. At dusk, as the sun sets, kneel facing west and swallow three more, following the dawn method as a regular practice. Avoid raw fish, pork, and Chinese chives; refrain from encountering funeral corpses, dogs, pigs, or childbirth filth. Be vigilant. This constitutes one dose.

Should the dose be exhausted and another prepared, calculate the proportions of the ingredients and combine them at will, ensuring the quantity suffices for a full year—this is most excellent for the practitioner. As for the pounding, increase the total by ten thousand strokes, making the combined pounding forty thousand in all. The celestial stems and earthly branches mark the path: *jiazi* initiates the cycle, *guihai* completes the count, with dawn and dusk as the appointed times. Take heed and never forget.

The sixty-one nodes are the constant of Heaven and Earth; follow the method in taking the pills. *Jia* and *gui* illuminate the way: from the *jiazi* day of establishment to the *guihai* day is one node. If *jiazi* lacks an establishment day, a full and fixed cycle will also suffice. Before taking the medicine, fast for three days, burn incense, and concentrate the spirit; only then proceed. After sixty days, the body feels light and able to walk; another sixty days, the four limbs become unobstructed; another sixty days, the complexion gains radiance; another sixty days, the abdomen and intestines harmonize, the five viscera grow firm, and malevolent influences cannot harm; another sixty days, the body becomes sturdy and strong; another sixty days, the ears and eyes grow wholly clear. These are the verifications of the first year.

After another sixty days, the bones and frame grow robust; another sixty days, the fingernails gleam; another sixty days, signs and portents become manifest; another sixty days, essence and *qi* flourish; another sixty days, white hair retreats; another sixty days, the teeth grow firm and hard. These are the verifications of the second year.

After another sixty days, virtue and the Dao attain thoroughfare; another sixty days, the Six *Jia* spirits follow; another sixty days, the spirit pervades the body; another sixty days, the will and faith move with the spirit; another sixty days, the heart opens and the eyes brighten; another sixty days, distant knowledge of the four directions arises. These are the verifications of the third year.

After another sixty days, the gaze shines with light; another sixty days, the five spirits do not depart; another sixty days, hunger and thirst are unknown; another sixty days, the hundred spirits come to pay homage; another sixty days, the five viscera never deplete; another sixty days, one endures both cold and heat. These are the verifications of the fourth year.

After another sixty days, one can float or sink; another sixty days, move shallow or deep; another sixty days, become round or square; another sixty days, grow weak or strong; another sixty days, extend or contract; another sixty days, shorten or lengthen. These are the verifications of the fifth year.

After another sixty days, one can be fair or foul; another sixty days, young or old; another sixty days, large or small; another sixty days, light or heavy; another sixty days, pass through barriers without hindrance; another sixty days, the traveling kitchen appears at one’s side, and one attains the rank of immortal. These are the verifications of the sixth year.

With unceasing practice, one aligns with Heaven, undergoes a thousand transformations, and ascends to the Great Clarity.

**Divine Treasure Grain-Winning Formula**
Transmitted by Immortal Huolin to Le Zichang, who concealed himself on the northern slopes of Mount Lao.

Grain-winner is also called sesame, *gou shi*, *moru*, "the lingering glory of the Three Luminaries," "the renewal of Heaven and Earth," *liuzhu*, "nine transformations," *youchang*, *hanyu*, and *qingxiang*. *Qingxiang* is the name of its leaf.

**Longevity-Extending Divine Formula**
Select fine sesame seeds, cleanse and remove impurities, steam them as in cooking, then dry in the sun. Repeat the steaming and drying nine times. Grind finely, sift, and form into pills with white honey, taking one the size of a chicken’s egg, three times daily. Another method states that if unable to form pills, take three *sheng* of the powdered medicine as a regular dose. After one year of practice, the complexion becomes beautiful and the body smooth and lustrous; after two years, white hair returns to black; after three years, fallen teeth regrow; after four years, one enters water without getting wet; after five years, one enters fire without burning; after six years, one can run as swiftly as a galloping horse. This medicine is sweet, fragrant, and delightful, easy to maintain and difficult to grow weary of. The formula is secret and rarely transmitted, passed down only once in a hundred years.

**Method for Consuming Sesame**
Take one *hu*, wash thoroughly, remove the black outer skin to reveal pure white, steam for one day, then dry in the sun. Grind or pound finely. Boil five *dou* of stones in a cauldron of water, then steam again, ensuring the cauldron retains a *shi*-worth of water. Place the sesame in a steamer, pour it into a wooden tray, and douse thoroughly with the stone-boiled water. Add one *dou* of finely ground wheat bran, mix, and ferment like sugar. Press out the dregs when done, then reduce the liquid by two-thirds over heat. Transfer to a copper vessel, float it in a cauldron of boiling water over a fierce fire, ensuring it does not cease boiling. Form into pills the size of a chicken’s egg. Taking three pills daily for a hundred days will replenish the flesh, turn the hair and temples black, and sharpen the ears and eyes. With prolonged practice, life knows no end.

**Sesame Paste**
Take one *dou* of sesame paste and three *jin* of scallion bulbs, simmer over a low fire until the scallions turn golden brown, then strain out the dregs. Take with wine, one *sheng* at midday. After a hundred days, the skin and flesh become full and flourishing; after two hundred days, the old grow young again; after three hundred days, one attains longevity. With prolonged practice, one becomes a divine immortal.

**Perfected One’s Grain-Abstention Formula**
Take two *dou* of grain-winner and five *sheng* of large pepper, remove the black skins, then pound and sift together. Initially take five *ge*, three times daily. Water infused with fermented grains may be used, or form into honey pills the size of a chicken’s egg, taking one four times daily. Gradually, hunger ceases. In times of famine, this medicine alone can replace grain. If thirsty, drink water only; consuming other foods will induce hunger. It multiplies strength a hundredfold, renders one immune to cold and heat, cures all illnesses, and naturally leads to immortality.

**Perfected One’s Grain-Abstention Method for Consuming Grain-Winner**
Take one *hu* of grain-winner, steam until the hot *qi* thoroughly permeates, then dry in the sun for one day. Repeat the steaming and drying nine times, requiring nine days in all.

When finished, pound and sift, then blend with white honey. Take pills the size of a chicken’s egg, three times daily. Over time, grain consumption naturally diminishes. After one hundred days of ingestion, all illnesses spontaneously heal, and water will not cling to the body. After one year, jade maidens attend as guardians.

For urgent use, steam and sun-dry three times daily, completing nine steams and nine dryings in three days before use. On overcast days, wait for the sun to emerge. For one *hu* of grain-winner, add three *jin* of *fuling* (Poria cocos), pound together, blend with honey, and ingest as above. The effects manifest more swiftly, replenishing essence and marrow, gradually eliminating hunger. Thirst may be quenched with water.

**Perfected One’s Light Grain Method for Abstaining from Coarse Food**
Take one *dou* and two *sheng* of grain-winner (pure black), twenty-four *liang* of *fuling*, and eight *liang* of *zexie* (Alisma). Process the three ingredients with ten thousand pestle strokes, then ingest pills the size of a bullet thrice daily. When food is available, eat; when not, consume any of the hundred foods without restriction.

**External Travel Method for Strengthening the Body**
Take five *sheng* of hemp seeds, soak in warm water until they split, then remove the skins. Combine the kernels with two *jin* of sheep fat and simmer over low heat until fully cooked, eating to satiety. Thirst may be quenched with water, and grains may be consumed freely. Prepare anew as before.

Hemp is the chief of the five grains, capable of discerning the myriad things and communing with divine luminaries. On the seventh day of the seventh month, take one *sheng* of hemp pollen and half a *jin* of true Shangdang ginseng, pound together, steam until *qi* emerges, and ingest one *daogui* (scant spoonful). No effect will fail to manifest.

**Discerning Chrysanthemum and *Yi* (Wild Chrysanthemum)**
Chrysanthemum flowers resemble *yi* flowers; distinguish them by taste—chrysanthemum is sweet, while *yi* is bitter. Chrysanthemums grow everywhere, though sparingly, often near water. In Goushi and Lixian, they are most abundant.

The Perfected One states: *Rijing* (Sun Essence), *Gengsheng* (Renewal), *Zhouying* (Fullness of Zhou), *Shenjing* (Divine Essence), and *Changsheng* (Longevity) are all one chrysanthemum, though their roots, stems, flowers, and seeds bear different names. The teachings are most refined, yet recent practitioners ingest them with little effect, precisely because they fail to obtain true chrysanthemum.

**Longevity-Extending Formula**
In spring, on the third month’s *jiayin* day, at noon, gather *Gengsheng* (the leaves). In summer, on the third month’s *bingyin* or *renzi* day, at noon, gather *Zhouying* (some texts say *Zhoucheng*). *Zhouying* is the chrysanthemum stem. In autumn, on the third month’s *gengyin* day, at the evening meal hour, gather *Rijing*. *Rijing* is the chrysanthemum flower. In winter, on the tenth month’s *wuyin* day, at dawn, gather *Shenjing*. *Shenjing* is also called *Shenhua* (Divine Flower) or *Shenying* (Divine Bloom)—the chrysanthemum seed. If no *wuyin* day is available, *renzi* may be used. In the eleventh or twelfth month, on *renyin* day at sunset, gather *Changsheng*. *Changsheng* is the chrysanthemum root. One text states: if no *renyin* day occurs in the eleventh month, *renzi* may be used.

Another text advises: combine all five ingredients, dry in the shade for one hundred days, then process two parts of each and sift. If the specified days for gathering are unavailable in any month, use *wuyin*, *wuzi*, *wuchen*, or *renzi* days instead.

In spring, add one part *Shenjing* and two parts *Gengsheng*; in summer, add three parts *Zhouying* and two parts *Gengsheng*; in autumn, add one part *Shenjing* and two parts *Rijing*; in winter, add three parts *Rijing*. Always compound on *zhicheng* days; never use *pori* or *weiri* days. One text states: do not adhere rigidly to days, lest the medicinal spirit fail to move. Pound in a secluded chamber, form pills with white pine resin, and take them the size of *wutong* seeds thrice daily after meals.

After one year of ingestion, all illnesses vanish, hearing sharpens, vision clarifies, the body lightens, *qi* increases, and lifespan extends by two years. After two years, the complexion glows, strength multiplies a hundredfold, white hair turns black, fallen teeth regrow, and lifespan extends by three years. After three years, one may traverse mountains without fear of serpents or dragons, avoid encounters with ghosts and spirits, evade blades and weapons, and cause birds to dare not fly nearby, extending lifespan by thirteen years. After four years, one gains communion with divine luminaries and the five phases, extending lifespan by forty years. After five years, the body emits radiance, the eyes shine day and night, light bridges barriers, joints become supple, and though wingless, one may fly at will. After six years, lifespan extends by three hundred years. After seven years, the Dao nears completion, extending lifespan by a thousand years. After eight years, one may see a thousand *li* and hear ten thousand *li*, extending lifespan by two thousand years. After nine years, the spirit is perfected, enabling transmutation of metal and stone, resurrection from death, and extending lifespan by three thousand years. A green dragon guards the left, a white tiger the right, and the chariot is wrought of gold.

Another text states: in spring, add two parts *Shenjing* and two parts *Gengsheng*; in summer, add one part *Shenjing* and two parts *Zhouying*; in autumn, add two parts *Rijing*; at the onset of winter, add two parts *Shenjing*; at the winter solstice, add one part *Shenjing* and two parts *Changsheng*. Swallow ten pills daily, five at dawn and five at dusk. One text states: in autumn, add one part *Shenjing* and two parts *Rijing*. Another text states: in spring, add two parts *Zhouying*.

**Method for Ingesting Apricot Seeds**
Take three *dou* of apricot seeds, discarding those with two kernels. Prepare boiling water, then immerse the apricots for a moment, rub to remove the skins, and process thoroughly. Place in a jar, strain the liquid, yielding seven or eight *dou* of juice. Discard the dregs, take a one-*shi* cauldron, place it over a fire of chaff or silkworm droppings, and rub four *jin* of sheep fat into the cauldron until fully absorbed. Heat again and rub in the fat until all four *jin* are exhausted. Pour the juice into the cauldron and simmer over the chaff or silkworm-dropping fire. After four or five days, the medicine is ready, its color like gold, resembling an infant’s chewed food.

Take a portion the size of a chicken’s yolk, thrice daily. After a hundred days of ingestion, even one’s parents will fail to recognize them, and their complexion will become radiant. The mother of Xia Zhengshu consumed this and lived seven hundred years before ascending as an immortal—this is a divine formula, to be kept secret.

**The Formula Bestowed upon Yu the Great by the Perfected One**
Recorded in the writings of Le Zichang, concealed on the northern slopes of Mount Lao.

**Red Arrow (赤箭)**
Also called *Limu* (离母), *Guidu You* (鬼督邮), *Divine Herb* (神草), *Solitary Sway* (独摇), *Dangku* (当苦), *Victory Child* (胜子), or *Ghost Arrow* (鬼箭).
It grows in Chen Cang, Mount Shaoshi, the Yaoliu Mountains of Shangluo, the southern slopes of Mount Tai, or the southern faces of renowned mountains, as well as in the streams and ravines of Nanyang or the shady recesses of valleys. A single stem bears nodes and leaves, its tips resembling bamboo leaves, unmoved even by wind. Harvest in the third month, taking the entire root without discarding any part. Pound and press to extract the juice, then set it in a vessel. Dry the dregs in the sun, then reintroduce the juice and dry again. Process and ingest a *fangcun* spoonful after meals to prevent aging. Effects manifest in ten days; after thirty, *qi* surges abundantly; after a hundred, the body lightens, hearing and vision sharpen, and within a year, teeth and hair regenerate. Its stem is red, like a bow and arrow, and its root resembles a human foot with toes but no nails. Its seeds resemble small lambs.

Another account states: the root resembles a taro corm, its seeds like taro kernels, growing beside it without attachment—often more than ten. In the morning, they lie west of the mother; by evening, east; at midday, beneath. Gather them all. At the center is a "king," as thick as a finger, with smaller ones like rings—twelve in total, three on each side, serving as its guards. To harvest, first purify oneself for a hundred days, then offer wine and dried meat to the mother. Under sunlight, gather the seeds, wrap them in a vermilion pouch, and keep it beneath the left armpit. The king is called *Six Jia Parents*, capable of concealing five hundred guards; its children can conceal one. If the mother plant dies in a household where childbirth occurs, the medicinal spirit departs.

Another account states: its leaves are as thick as a thumb, with four red "feathers" extending above and below. It grows year-round, and can be harvested at any time. It governs malevolent ghosts, spectral entities, *gu* toxins, pernicious *qi*, alternating chills and fevers, abscesses, and swelling. It invigorates *yin*, augments *qi*, strengthens the body, and lightens the frame. Prolonged use extends lifespan. Its flavor is bitter.

**Pokeweed Root (章陆根)**
Acrid and toxic, it dispels pathogenic *qi* from the chest, reduces swelling when applied topically, eliminates spectral entities, refines the five viscera, and disperses water *qi*. Roots resembling human forms are imbued with spirit. Harvest from abandoned ruins or fields in the third and eighth months.

**Pokeweed (章陆草)**
Also called *Yehu* (夜呼), *Danggen* (荡根), *Danglu* (当陆), *Xianlu* (苋陆), *Longgen* (长根), *Shanglu Grass* (商陆草), *Divine Reed* (神陆), *White Blossom* (白华), *Dispel Evil* (逐邪), *Heavenly Herb* (天草), or *Expeller of Yin Spirits* (逐阴之精). This is a divine herb.
It expels the Three Worms, slays dormant corpses, treats facial darkening, enhances intelligence, prevents forgetfulness, and cures the Five Taxations, Seven Injuries, women’s postpartum ailments, and red-and-white vaginal discharge. The formula: ten *jin* of pokeweed, three *dou* of rice, and one *dou* of processed *tianmen dong* powder. Soak the pokeweed for six days, then consume while fasting. After five days, hunger vanishes; after twenty, the intestines grow plump, the countenance becomes refined, the breath sweet, all worms depart, hearing and vision sharpen, and scars fade. On days when the moon lodges with ghosts, at the *ding* hour, harvest *shanglu* and ingest a portion the size of a jujube, thrice daily. Daoists cultivate this herb in the gardens of secluded chambers to commune with spirits. It prevents aging, bestows longevity, expels the Three Worms, and cures all poisons, rendering them harmless.

**Formula for Longevity, Expelling the Three Corpses, and Reversing Gray Hair**
One should ingest the mother of *Dan Guang* (丹光) and consume the marrow of *Floating Water* (浮水)—these arise naturally. After a thousand years, they transform; after a hundred, they transmute. First transformation, then transmutation: Heaven can no longer harm, and gods and ghosts are powerless. Thus, they may be ingested, and thus, one attains life.

The mother of *Dan Guang* is pine resin. The marrow of *Floating Water* is *fuling* (茯苓). They subdue ghosts and spirits, avert death, and restore life. Pine resin that seeps into the earth transforms into *xia ling* (狭苓) after a thousand years; *fuling* transmutes into amber after a thousand years; amber becomes *Dan Guang* after a thousand years—*Dan Guang* is purple and luminous. After another thousand years, *Dan Guang* becomes *Fei Jie Zhi* (蜚节芝); *Fei Jie Zhi* becomes the marrow of *Floating Water* after a thousand years; the marrow of *Floating Water* becomes *Ye Guang* (夜光) after a thousand years; *Ye Guang* becomes *Jin Jing* (金精) after a thousand years; *Jin Jing* becomes a shooting star after a thousand years; a shooting star becomes *Shi Dan* (石胆) after a thousand years; *Shi Dan* becomes *Jin Gang* (金刚) after a thousand years; and *Jin Gang* becomes *Mu Wei Xi Zhi* (木威僖芝) after a thousand years. Gold, when cast into fire, does not diminish; when placed in water, it thrives.

The transformations of pine resin are ever without fixed form, thus it may sink and pervade without bound or ascend to the Great Clarity. This is the method of the flying immortals—do not transmit it to the unworthy.

The formula states: First take twelve *jin* each of pine resin and *fuling*. Soak the *fuling* and pine resin in water for seven days, then drain the water at sunrise. Mix the *fuling* with two *dou* of pure wine and consume it, drying it in the sun. Eat one *jin* per month, and you will no longer need to eat.

Next, refine the pine resin to remove its bitterness and odor. Warm it with fire, then blend it with the *fuling* and mix with white honey. Combine these three substances and consume one *jin* per month. After a hundred days, the body becomes light; after two hundred days, chills and fever depart; after three hundred days, wind in the head, chest, and eyes is dispelled; after four hundred days, the five taxations and seven injuries vanish; after five hundred days, cold accumulations, phlegm-rheum, and qi bind in the abdomen are removed; after six hundred days, the complexion stabilizes; after seven hundred days, blemishes fade; after eight hundred days, black hair grows; after nine hundred days, scars from moxibustion disappear; after a thousand days, the eyes become bright; after two thousand days, the complexion renews; after three thousand days, one leaves no footprints; after four thousand days, all marks vanish; after five thousand days, one sees light at night; after six thousand days, the flesh renews; after seven thousand days, skin and vessels are concealed; after eight thousand days, the spirit is strong; after nine thousand days, one resembles a youth; after ten thousand days, the form is naturally sound; after twenty thousand days, the spirit is enlightened; after thirty thousand days, one manifests in broad daylight; after forty thousand days, the Great One welcomes you; after fifty thousand days, one sits in disappearance and stands in vanishing.

Consume it thrice daily, taking care never to forget. After ten thousand days, you may roam freely, change your name and surname, and ascend to the imperial heavens.

In ancient times, there was a man named Huang Chuping. By faithfully consuming this medicine, he became a perfected one. Chuping was from Danxi. At the age of fifteen, his family sent him to herd sheep. A Daoist, seeing his goodness and diligence, took him to a stone chamber in Mount Jinhua, where he remained for over forty years, suddenly ceasing to think of home. His elder brother, Chuqi, searched for Chuping for years without success. Later, he encountered a Daoist in the marketplace and asked, "My younger brother was herding sheep and has been lost for over forty years. I do not know whether he is alive or dead. I beg you, Daoist, to divine his whereabouts." The Daoist replied, "On Mount Jinhua, there is a boy who herds sheep, surnamed Huang, named Chuping—he is your brother." Chuqi, upon hearing this, followed the Daoist and found his brother. After exchanging joyful and sorrowful words, Chuqi asked Chuping, "Where are the sheep you once herded?" Chuping replied, "The sheep are just east of the mountain." Chuqi went to look but saw no sheep—only white stones. Returning, he said to Chuping, "There are no sheep east of the mountain." Chuping replied, "The sheep are there—it is only that you cannot see them." They went together, and Chuping shouted, "Sheep, rise!" At once, the white stones all stood up and became sheep—tens of thousands of them. Chuqi said, "You alone have attained the Dao to such a degree—can I learn it?" Chuping replied, "Only if you are devoted to the Way." Chuqi then abandoned his wife and children, staying with Chuping to consume pine resin and *fuling*. After fifty thousand days, he could sit in disappearance and stand in vanishing, walking at midday without a shadow, his complexion like that of a youth. Together, they returned to their hometown, where nearly all their relatives had died, so they departed again. Chuping taught the formula to Nan Bo Feng, changing his surname to Chi. Chuqi changed his name to Chi Luban, and Chuping changed his name to Chi Songzi. Thereafter, thousands of people who consumed this medicine became immortals.

**Chi Songzi’s Formula**
On the sixteenth day of the seventh month, remove the fingernails and toenails to expel the Three Corpses worms from the abdomen.

**Perpetual Mountain-Dwelling Non-Food Formula**
Use ten parts of soybeans, three parts of *weirui*, one part of *zexie*, one part of *feiying*, and half a part of *gaoben* leaves. Grind these five ingredients into powder, mix with jujube pulp, and form pills the size of plums. Swallow three daily, along with twenty-one jujubes, and you may go without food for life. If jujubes are unavailable, regularly drink Jade Spring water.

**The Yellow Emperor’s Four-Substance Immortal Formula of Yellow Lightness**
The first is *Hongguang*, the second is *Qianqiu*, the third is *Wansui*, and the fourth is *Cimo shi*. Combine these four substances, forming pills with white pine resin the size of chicken eggs. Consuming them for seven years grants a lifespan of forty-three thousand years without death. Taking them continuously allows one to endure with heaven and earth.

The Yellow Emperor asked, "What do the forms of these four substances resemble? May I hear of them?"
Huang Qing replied, "Hongguang is mica. Qianqiu is curled cypress, growing among mountain stones. Wansui is *zexie*. Cimo is amaranth seed. Form them into pills with pine resin, the size of chicken eggs. Consume one pill at dusk each day, and one will endure forever, free from hunger and thirst."

**Perfected One’s Four-Substance Grain-Avoidance Powder**
Use three parts of *fuling* powder, one part of dried *dihuang* powder, one part of *huma* powder, and one part of *tianmen dong* powder. Parch the *huma* over fire. Grind these four ingredients together, mix with honey, and consume a square *cun* spoonful daily, taking it with fine rice-water wine. After thirty days, one’s strength will differ; after a hundred days, it will double; after a year, the complexion will be like clouds, and one will dream of wandering with spirits; after three years, the bones will soar and the flesh will fly.

**Sophora**
Sophora is the essence of the Void Star. Long-term consumption rejuvenates the old, prevents brain depletion, and enhances the complexion. On the *shangsi* day of the tenth month, gather sophora seeds and place them in a new clay jar. Cover it with a clay basin, seal it with mud, and open it after twenty-one days. Wash the seeds, and their outer skins will peel away, leaving the kernels like soybeans. Begin consumption on the first day of the month: one seed on the first day, two on the second, three on the third, increasing by one each day until the tenth day. In ten days, consume fifty-five seeds. In a long month, consume one hundred sixty-five; in a short month, do not follow the long-month count.

In one year, consume one thousand nine hundred eighty seeds. Since a year has six short months, subtract sixty seeds.

**Another Method for Consuming Sophora to Treat Illness**
On the *shangsi* day of the tenth month, gather sophora seeds and dry them in the shade for one hundred days. Pound them to remove the skins, then place the kernels in a clay vessel. Begin consumption on the first day: one seed on the first day, ten seeds on the tenth day, then restart from one. Follow this pattern for ten days, then repeat as before. To treat sudden illnesses, stagnant fluids, undigested food, chest fullness, diarrhea, or dysentery: take one *ge* at a time, and recovery will follow after two *ge*. There is no toxicity in large doses. If the patient has a poor appetite, do not administer too much, as it may cause hard, difficult bowel movements.

**Method for Expelling the Three Worms**
Gather sophora seeds—no need to wait for the *shangsi* day. Collect them with their skins intact, pound them into a paste, and form into pills the size of apricot kernels. Take three pills per dose, twice daily. Preparing a larger quantity for long-term use is also beneficial. Alternatively, they may be made into honey pills.

**Longevity Formula**
Use ripe sophora seeds, place them inside ox intestines, and dry in the shade for one hundred days. Then, swallow one seed at morning and evening meals. After ten days, the body will feel light; after thirty days, white hair will turn black; after one hundred days, the complexion will glow; after two hundred days, one will outrun a galloping horse.

**Rejuvenation Formula**
On the *shangsi* day of the tenth month, consume one sophora seed, increasing by one each day until the tenth day, then restart from one. The preparation should be made on the *shangsi* day itself.

**The Single-Ingredient Lotus Powder, Bestowed by the True Person for Monthly Use**
Gather seven *fen* of lotus flowers on the seventh day of the seventh month, eight *fen* of lotus roots on the eighth day of the eighth month, and nine *fen* of lotus seeds on the ninth day of the ninth month. Combine them to complete the formula. Take one *fangcun* spoonful, as taught to Liu Changsheng of Nanyang. Changsheng dwells in the northern reaches of Qingyuan Marsh. Having consumed the formula for over seventy years, he neither ages nor weakens. To verify its efficacy, feed it to a chick the size of a myna bird: after three years, it will remain a fledgling, proving the formula’s power to confer immortality.

Lotus seeds are also called *water red lingzhi*, *qie* seeds, *qian* seeds, lotus flowers, or hibiscus. Their leaves are called *he*, their small roots *yu*, their large roots *ou*, and their initial roots *jiao*. Together with *qianshi* (fox nut), they form a yin-yang pair. On the *shangxu* day of the eighth month, gather lotus pods; on the *shangxu* day of the ninth month, gather fox nut seeds; and on the *shangwu* day of the ninth month, gather lotus roots. Dry each in the shade for one hundred days, then process them in equal parts. On the first *shangmao* day of the first month at dawn, take one *fangcun* spoonful with well-water, four or five times daily, followed by meals. Continue for one hundred days. This formula tonifies the center, augments qi and strength, nourishes the spirit, eliminates hunger, dispels all illnesses, and with prolonged use, lightens the body, extends life, prevents aging, and bestows immortality.

Fox nut seeds are also called *yan* seeds, *heavenly gate essence*, *heavenly Yu*, or *yao*. Their sweet flavor treats damp impediment, lumbar and spinal pain, supplements and boosts qi, strengthens the will, sharpens hearing and vision, and with prolonged use, lightens the body, eliminates hunger, and bestows immortality.

**Longevity Formula**
On the *zhicheng* day of the eighth month, gather lotus seeds; on the *zhicheng* day of the ninth month, gather fox nut seeds. Dry them in the shade for one hundred days, then pound and combine in equal parts. On the *zhicheng* day, take one *fangcun* spoonful with well-water. After one hundred days, the strong will no longer age, and the old will regain youth. If in doubt, feed the formula to a chick for one hundred days to witness its effects. Prolonged use bestows immortality.

**Deer Antler Formula for Longevity, Enhancing Hearing and Vision, and Blackening Hair**
Take fresh antlers, scrape away the black skin with a knife, and collect the white inner portion. Roast until yellow, then process thoroughly. Take one *fangcun* spoonful twice daily. After thirty days, one will attain divine clarity; after sixty days, strength will increase a hundredfold; after one hundred days, one will commune with spirits. With continuous use, life will be boundless and longevity infinite. Peng Zigao and Rong Cheng consumed it to attain immortality, while Fan Li took it to wander among the people.

**Yellow Essence Herb**
The yellow essence herb is the essence of the Great Yang. It gathers qi from the nine heavens, drifts through the eight expanses, follows the wind’s transformations, and scatters its essence across the six directions. It takes root beside mountains, borrows its name from the clouds and rain, and assumes its form by clinging to light. As a plant, it grows on the slopes of Mount Taihang, its roots clinging to the sides of boulders. Embracing the essence of the three yangs, it flourishes with the qi, nurturing purity and harmony, tempering sweet dew. Above, it receives the Great Fire of the Lesser Yang, blooming in the height of summer. Accumulating essence to refine its truth, it fills its roots and multiplies its nodes. Its color is yellow, its flavor sweet. At dawn, it turns toward the sun, its veins and textures unobstructed. Unlike other plants, it does not wither in drought, and no other being rivals its singularity. This is the dwelling of the Central Yellow, the ancestral source of accumulated yang—its divine transformations are wondrous indeed.

When serpents consume it, they transform into dragons; when birds consume it, they become phoenixes; when humans consume it, they become immortal kings. Great is this herb, for it captures the pure essence of heaven and earth. Yet the people of the world do not know its truth; those who know it cannot consume it. Thus, the *Scripture of the Great Immortals of the Nine Heavens* states: "Thirty-six thousand spirits of heaven and earth enter the human body, yet none can be harnessed. Thirty-six thousand immortality elixirs exist, yet none are used. Long life and enduring vision are possible, yet none achieve them. Divine sagacity can be attained, and lifespan extended, yet none comprehend the way. Though the spirits are luminous, and the effects of consuming the elixirs are swift and evident, none persist in the practice."

People cling to poverty and lowliness to nurture their bodies, yet I have never seen one attain long life and enduring vision. Those who chase power and profit do so eagerly in the present age. If people sought long life with the same fervor as they seek profit, none would fail to attain it. Those who can relinquish glory and splendor, cultivate stillness and purity, embrace constant non-action, and seek the mysterious and wondrous—consuming this herb without fail through the four seasons—may achieve extended life. If one can renounce the mundane world, dwell in seclusion in the famous mountains, and consume this herb, one may stand peerless with heaven and earth, gather with the host of spirits, receive the welcome of the Great One, ascend to the celestial palace, and wander Kunlun. One may thus share the beginning and end of heaven and earth.

This herb stands opposite to *goumian*. *Huangjing* is the essence of the Great Yang, and when ingested, it grants long life. *Goumian*, however, is the essence of the Great Yin, and when taken, it brings immediate death—yet people remain unaware of their opposition. They believe only in *goumian*’s power to kill but not in *huangjing*’s power to give life, and so they do not consume it.

*Goumian* is wild aconite. In the southern mountains of Rinan, the barbarian tribes call wild aconite *goumian*. When eaten, it kills instantly, its poison seething and vengeful, its qi hooking into the intestines and severing them—hence the name *goumian*. This is what it means when people neglect long life in their craving for fleeting glory.

Only *huangjing*, among all herbs and trees, embodies the qi of the Three Yangs. It ascends into the Palace of Great Purity, refining its essence into profound wonder, transforming with the flow of pure harmony. Its radiance streams across the Nine Wilds, spreading through the Six Directions. It hides in clouds and conceals itself in mountains, shifting form with the qi. Its roots take hold, its stems rise, its leaves transmit essence, and its sweet, fragrant taste forms. Its leaves are green and yellow, connecting with spirits and transcending union. Ten thousand roots grow downward, catching the wind and bearing dew. Its roots knot in several nodes, slanting and branching sideways. It receives pure, hidden qi and exhales to nurture the true. Its flowers possess nine virtues, enhancing longevity and advancing wisdom. Its stems hold numinous treasures—consuming them makes one an immortal. Its roots are celestial treasures, harmonizing light and commanding spirits. Taken as a powdered elixir, they enable flight as a transcendent.

In late spring, gather its roots—called *mountain essence*—wash them in clear water, and place them in a large tray. Carefully prepare them for consumption, either fresh or dried. When dried, they become powder; when fresh, they form pills. Consuming much allows one to abstain from grains, while taking little calms the spirit. Whether root or flower, all three grades of ingestion yield the same effect. With years of accumulation, one attains spiritual transcendence. The flowers are *flying blossoms*, the roots *flowing essence*. Together, they nourish the inner spirits, transforming one’s spirit into numinosity, illuminating with penetrating clarity, sharpening vision across a thousand miles. They bind the hun and anchor the po, balancing the Five Viscera, driving out the Three Worms, subduing the corpse-reflex, and dispelling fright. With regular consumption, heaven and earth merge as one.

Its roots are yellow, not white; its leaves soft and lustrous. It receives pure, untainted qi, unlike ordinary plants. While a hundred grasses wither and fade with autumn, *huangjing* flourishes, concealing the Dao and harboring virtue. Its numinous stalks sway gently, its flowers and leaves gleaming. In mid-spring, gather its blossoms, place them in a silk pouch, and dry them in the shade under the Six Ding days, with the Jade Maiden at one’s side. Consuming them for a thousand days, one may sit in death or stand in disappearance.

Its spring and autumn leaves and roots harmonize yin and yang. Formed into pills or cakes, they reveal a sweet, fragrant taste. The amount consumed depends on one’s intention—there is no fixed measure. Its stems and leaves, rich in essence, yield a juice that serves as a broth, broadening the center and replenishing qi. The Five Viscera are regulated, the flesh plumps, the bones strengthen, and one’s strength surpasses that of youth. The body thrives in health, and immortals consume it as their supreme sustenance.

**Numinous Treasure Huangjing Formula**
In spring, take the roots, wash them clean, and slice thinly. Steam thoroughly, then dry in the sun until crisp. Pound and take a square-inch spoonful—best done in the open air. It is also called *horse arrow*, *mianbamboo*, *weirui*, *keju*, *sheep’s clasp*, *immortal’s surplus grain*, *gouge*, and *hanging pearl*. Its leaves are called *chicken’s clasp root*; it is also named *huangjing*, *white fern*, and *baiqi*. Gather the roots in the third month for consumption. It lightens the body, replenishes qi, and brightens the eyes. Eating it allows one to endure hunger. Its taste is sweet and non-toxic. Dried in the shade for fifty days, it matures. Take a peck of its fruit, soak it in sweet water, and use two pecks to make a broth or wine. Regular consumption ensures immortality.

Consuming *huangjing* roots yields many benefits. Wash and scrape them to remove all soil. Boil one *hu* of roots in two *hu* of water until the flavor is fully extracted. Strain and boil again, repeating until the essence is exhausted. Combine and simmer the liquid until it thickens, then remove from heat and mix with roasted soybean powder to form cakes the size of coins. Consume as desired—the taste is sweet and fragrant. The roots may also be steamed or boiled and eaten without restriction.

When it first sprouts, its stems and leaves may be taken as vegetables for fasting meals—this is the *double-storied* of the day. If boiled, the broth may be drunk—do not discard it, for it is fragrant and delicious.

**Method for Consumption**
In the second and eighth months, gather the roots, scrape off the hairs, wash thoroughly, and slice finely. Boil one *hu* of roots in six *dou* of water over a gentle fire until the medicine is done by evening. Remove and let cool, then knead by hand to break it apart. Use a wine bag to press out the juice, then simmer until it thickens enough to form pills. Dry the residue into powder, mix it into the pot, and blend until the medicine is ready. Take pills the size of chicken eggs, three times daily. This allows one to abstain from grains without hunger or cold, to run as swiftly as a galloping horse, and to cure all illnesses.

One who can abstain from the bedchamber will not age and may attain boundless longevity as an immortal. Without such abstinence, one may still live two hundred years. Consuming this medicine, one need not fear tigers or wolves, nor dread weapons of war. When traveling in the mountains, one may eat it raw, drink water freely when thirsty, and consume it fresh. It also enhances communion with the divine and may be taken as a powder—ingestion is not strictly necessary.

Consuming *huangjing* prevents aging, restores youthful complexion, turns white hair black, and makes fallen teeth regrow. After thirty days, one gains clarity of spirit; after a hundred days, one may leap and run like a galloping horse without fatigue. After two hundred days, one may appear and vanish at will. After ten years, the Dao of immortality is achieved. Many have witnessed its efficacy, and past generations often consumed this formula.

Some consume only the flowers—the essence of *huangjing*, also called *yellow blossom*. Its taste is sweet and fragrant. Boil its "mother" (root) to make a drink that broadens the center, replenishes qi, and wards off malign qi. Regular consumption imparts a radiant complexion and resilience to cold and heat. It is also called *salvation-from-poverty grain*, for in famine years, both young and old may rely on it to survive without other food. Consuming its flowers surpasses its fruit, and its fruit surpasses its roots.

The Celestial Officials name this herb *Wuji Zhi*. In ancient times, one who entered the Red City within Mount Huo saw therein several thousand households, all tilling the fields and cultivating this herb—some planting dozens of *qing*, others merely dozens of *mu*. Their roots and stems grew exceptionally large, for they were diligently tended and hoed, unlike those that sprouted wild in the mountains. It thrives in marshes and wetlands.

The traveler asked the people of Red City, “Why do you cultivate this herb?” They replied, “This is an herb of immortality. The people here have long consumed it to attain longevity.” When Sun Quan, Lord of Wu, heard this account and verified its truth, he dispatched men to cultivate it in the mountains of Jiangdong and consume it. Yet Sun Quan did not abstain from the bedchamber, nor maintain stillness in his conduct, and thus failed to reap its benefits. At the time, overseers and soldiers were stationed to guard the fields. Though Wu fell, the name of this place endured. In Jiangdong, it is sometimes called *Mianzhu Li*, or *Yellow Li*, the very site where Sun Quan once planted it.

Disciple Ge Hong once heard from Master Zheng of its origins, who said:
*“Consume Wuji, and life shall not end;
Consume the essence of longevity,
And stand peerless beneath heaven.”*

I have also heard from the transmission of Immortal Ge Xian’gong: “Those who cultivate the Dao of longevity must first expel the Three Worms and subdue the Lying Corpses before engaging in medicinal fasting and grain avoidance. Without expelling the Three Worms and Lying Corpses, those who abstain from grain will be plagued by cravings, harming the body. Moreover, they may encounter tempting foods, leading to distraction and transgression.

The highest path is to practice non-action, ingest natural qi, and rinse with sweet springs. Most cannot achieve this, so they may rely on herbs to assist—first subduing the Lying Corpses, then consuming the medicine, which yields efficacy. This is the secondary path of the Dao.

When compounding medicine, choose an auspicious day under a clear sky, free of clouds, and form the pills in a secluded place. Do not speak of the medicine while preparing it. The Three Worms, though earless, hear; though eyeless, see. First bathe with orchid-scented water, fast for three days, avoid women, and abstain from pork and dog meat. Consuming these meats leads to death, barring ascent to heaven—one is confined to Mount Tai, cast into the Three Officials’ hell, and becomes a ghostly warden. This rule applies to Daoist practitioners.

Furthermore, avoid pork and dog meat, for they cause forgetfulness in old age, a sallow complexion, tooth decay, and a ruined voice. Those who consume purity attain longevity; those who consume filth meet their end. The crane does not kill living things, hence its thousand-year lifespan; the swan does not tread black waters, hence its century-long life. Purity begets truth; clarity begets longevity—this is the natural order.”

**Formula for Expelling the Three Worms and Lying Corpses**
Use ten *jin* of *fuling*, five *jin* of *zhanglu* root (peeled to retain only the white inner part), five *dou* each of clear wine and wheat yeast. Steam and ferment them in a jar, sealing it for twenty days. Once the medicine is ready, shape it into a paste. Take pure, roasted soybeans, grind them into a syrup-like powder, and form pills the size of large marbles. Consume three pills daily. After ten days, the effects will gradually manifest.

The Upper Corpse, resembling a hand, emerges after a hundred days—black in color.
The Middle Corpse, resembling a foot, emerges after sixty days—blue in color.
The Lower Corpse, resembling a chicken egg, emerges after thirty days—white in color.
All will rot and be expelled.

**The Three Corpses and Their Nature**

The Three Corpses are born within man and ever seek his death. On the last day of the lunar month and the first day of the new moon, they ascend to heaven to report his transgressions. When the last day arrives, one must restrain the *hun* and subdue the *po*, and on the night of *gengshen*, remain vigilant—thus the Three Corpses cannot stir. On such nights, if one dreams of struggling with another, it is the *po* contending with the Corpses. The *hun* ever desires tranquility, yet the body resists submission to the Corpses; the *po* ever seeks calm, yet the spirit inclines toward distraction. The Three Corpses, desiring man’s death, strive to assail and seize him—such is their nature.

Most Daoist adepts and physicians merely follow formulas to treat the body, unaware that the Lying Corpses dwell within the abdomen, obstructing the efficacy of medicines—all the work of the Three Worms. The Upper Corpse craves boundless wealth, the Middle Corpse delights in the five flavors, and the Lower Corpse lusts after the five colors. If they are not expelled, one merely deceives oneself. Once purged, hunger ceases, the mind becomes still and free of thoughts, and one may attain longevity.

The Perfected value this formula, Daoists revere its medicine, the wise delight in its use, while the foolish scoff at the practice. Thus, when men speak of the dead as "corpses," it is by virtue of these Three Worms’ designations.

To prepare the *zhanglu* powder is sufficient to expel the Three Corpses—fermentation is not strictly necessary. Sophora seeds are also effective. Those who practice *qi*-absorption need not employ this method.

Moreover, true *qi* is the "green sprout," the essence of the five directions. If a Daoist ingests it for twenty-one days, the Three Worms will flee.

**Le Zichang’s Refined Sesame Paste Formula**
Take two *dou* of sesame paste and one *dou* of water, combine with two *sheng* of frankincense and two *sheng* of aloeswood, grind into powder, and boil until the water evaporates, leaving only the paste. Mix the powder into it. Consume five *ge* daily with wine. After a hundred days, jade maidens will attend you—its efficacy is divine. After five hundred days, immortals will come to escort you away. This formula is a closely guarded secret of the Daoist tradition, never lightly transmitted.

**Le Zichang’s Sesame Method**
Roast one *dou* of sesame until fragrant, then pound it into fine powder. Place it in a silk bag and steep in five *dou* of wine, sealing it for twenty days. Consume the wine, which becomes infused with sesame essence. The powder may also be ingested directly.

**The Numinous Treasure’s Supreme Mystery Yin-Generating Talisman**
A script of Xia Yu, received from the Perfected One of Mount Zhong. The Way of Corpse-Release for Lesser Immortals. Its lifespan matches that of heaven and earth, allowing one to wander sacred mountains as an Earth Immortal.

After completing the prescribed days of the Corpse-Release elixir, inscribe this talisman in cinnabar on white silk and place it before the abdomen. On a *wu* or *ji* day, lie with the head to the west, meditate upon oneself as a corpse, and after a long while, remove the garments and leave them where one lay. Depart immediately for the mountains. If traveling far, change one’s name and never return to the former home. Initially, others will see a corpse where one lay, but after some time, it will vanish without a trace.

**Corpse-Release Elixir**
In the third month, slaughter an ox and render one and a half *jin* of its fat. Combine with one and a half *jin* each of mercury and tin. Seclude oneself in the mountains for a month of purification, then melt the tin in a bronze vessel. Once liquefied, add the mercury and fat, blending them into pills the size of large soybeans. Consume three pills thrice daily. After nine days—eighty-one pills in total—one will suddenly undergo Corpse-Release, shedding the body like a snake’s slough. Depart as instructed by the talisman above. If unsuccessful, consume more and hasten the process until release is achieved.

The Perfected One says: Use cinnabar for the script, fresh silk for the cloth, and a fresh silk pouch for storage. The ancients called cinnabar "vermilion child" and silk "fresh support."

**Formula for Expelling the Three Worms and Lying Corpses**
On the third day of the third month, gather peach leaves, pound them to extract seven *sheng* of juice, and boil with vinegar until reduced to five or six *ge*. Consume on an empty stomach in one dose.

**Divine Immortal’s Cultivation and Nourishment Formula**
Render one *dou* of ox or sheep fat on an auspicious day. Combine with one *dou* of sesame, one hundred pieces of dried ginger, half a *jin* of fresh ginger, and one *jin* of fresh rehmannia, then press to extract the juices. Simmer in a large bronze pot over low heat until the medicinal essence is exhausted and the fat turns yellow. Strain and discard the dregs. Take a portion the size of a chicken egg, dissolve in wine, and consume thrice daily. It cures all ailments, restores black hair, and renews teeth.

**Divine Immortal’s Wine Formula**
Take ten *jin* of fresh rehmannia, three *jin* of fresh ginger (peeled), and five *jin* of asparagus root (peeled), then chop and pound them together into a mash. Steep in one *hu* of fine wine, dividing it between two jars. Seal tightly and place the jars in a large cauldron to steam until the stoppers emit hot, billowing vapor. Consume one *sheng* warm daily before sleep, sensing the radiant *qi* of the medicine coursing through the body. This wine replenishes deficiency and taxation, augments essence and *qi*, strengthens appetite, fortifies against wind and cold, enhances complexion, and imparts lustrous skin, prolonging life.

**Atractylodes Wine Formula**
Grind five *dou* of processed atractylodes into powder, place in a silk bag, and steep in one *hu* of fine wine for ten days. Remove the atractylodes, dry it in the sun, and reserve. Take three *fangcunbi* of the powder with wine thrice daily—divinely effective for all ailments. Alternatively, mix with glutinous rice porridge, ferment into wine, and consume; eating the dregs is also beneficial.

**Divine Wine Formula**
Cures all diseases, replenishes essence, augments *qi*, and beautifies the complexion. Take three *jin* of cassia (or a three-*chi* length, finely processed to retain only the inner bark) and five *sheng* of asparagus root powder, place in a silk bag, and steep in five *dou* of rice wine until fermented. Consume as desired.

**Sesame Wine Formula**
Roast five *dou* of sesame until fragrant, then pound into fine powder. Mix into one *hu* of glutinous rice porridge and ferment as usual. Once ready, drink as desired. It plumps the body, whitens the skin, and imparts a lustrous complexion.

**Rehmannia Divine Wine Formula**
Prepare five *dou* of glutinous rice porridge, strain to yield two *dou* of liquid, then add three *jin* of fine wheat yeast, allowing the wine’s fragrance to rise. Take ten *jin* of fresh rehmannia root, briefly sun-dry, then thoroughly pound. Steam one *dou* of rice into cooked grains, mix into the liquid, and stir well. Seal with clay for a day, then check if the rehmannia is softened—only fibrous strands should remain. Strain the dregs, steam another two *dou* of rice, and add to the wine until fully fermented. Drink one *sheng* thrice daily. It cures all diseases, remedies the five taxations and seven injuries, knits bones and sinews, replenishes marrow, and with prolonged use, extends lifespan.

**Pine Resin Wine Formula**
Use three *dou* of glutinous rice and two *jin* of wheat yeast to brew wine as usual. Then add one *jin* of white pine resin, five *sheng* each of asparagus root powder and poria powder, sealing with clay for thirty days until mature. Consume three *sheng* at once to prolong life. The pine resin must first be refined to remove its bitter taste.

**Alternative Pine Resin Wine Formula**
Brew three *dou* of glutinous rice with three *jin* of wheat yeast, then add one *jin* of pine resin and five *sheng* of white honey. Seal with clay for thirty days; once ready, drink three *sheng* morning and evening.

**Pokeweed Wine Formula**
Use three *dou* of glutinous rice, ten *jin* of wheat yeast, and one *dou* of asparagus root powder. Process pokeweed roots until white, dry, and grind into ten *jin* of powder. Ferment together for sixty days, then strain the dregs. Drink as desired. Prolonged use eliminates the need for grain, plumps the abdomen, augments *qi*, expels the three worms, eradicates dormant pathogens, and treats the five taxations and seven injuries in men and women, as well as postpartum ailments and vaginal discharge (red or white). It sharpens hearing and vision, enhances mental acuity, and erases facial blemishes and scars. One variant uses only one *jin* of pokeweed.

**Lycium Berry Wine Formula**
Wash and clean one hundred *jin* of lycium roots, finely chop, and boil in a large cauldron with ample water. Strain the liquid, let it settle in a vessel, and decant five *dou* of clear juice. Wash thirty *jin* of fresh rehmannia root, pound, and extract its juice, then combine with the lycium juice. Use three *jin* of yeast, finely ground, and five *dou* of red glutinous rice, steaming the rice with the medicinal juice. Once cooked, mix with the yeast and ferment in the combined juices. Drink the matured wine as desired, without restriction—only avoid intoxication. It cures all diseases, boosts *qi* and strength, and extends lifespan.

This herb is also called *mengchai*, *chunlü*, *xianrenzhang*, *xiwangmu zhang*, *tianjing*, *queshu*, *digou*, or *gouqi*. With eight names, it corresponds to the eight *qi*. The immortals say: "If you wish to live long, consume my eight *qi*; by ingesting them, you shall see far."

**Five-Leaf Ginseng Wine Formula**
Chop five-leaf ginseng into one-*cun* segments; one *dou* of chopped herb yields one *dou* of material. Steep in fine wine for ten days. Drink warm, in moderation. It sharpens hearing and vision, regrows fallen teeth, restores black hair, lightens the body, strengthens vitality, and enhances complexion. It treats impotence, postpartum ailments, and all diseases in women, promoting fertility. Select only the male variety (five leaves, sweet taste); avoid the female (three leaves, bitter taste).

**Asparagus Root Wine Formula**
Harvest the roots in autumn, wash, and extract juice as desired. Soak rice and yeast in the juice, fermenting as usual. Drink without restriction, avoiding only excessive intoxication. Alternatively, dry the roots into powder and take with this wine—more is better. This remedy cures all diseases, calms the spirit, nourishes *qi*, and grants immortality. It is the formula once used by Lady Xia. If juice extraction is incomplete, rinse the roots with water, pound again, and strain. Over time, the wine may sour; store it in a jar and boil in a cauldron to prevent spoilage.

One variant prescribes taking a square-inch spoonful three to four times daily—more is better.

**Asparagus Root Decoction Formula**
Treats consumptive diseases, suspended fluid beneath the heart causing loss of appetite, and thirst. It plumps the body and ensures eternal youth. Use two hundred *jin* of asparagus root and one hundred *jin* of fresh rehmannia root, both thoroughly washed. Pound and extract the juice, then decant the clear liquid: one *hu* of asparagus juice and five *dou* of rehmannia juice. Combine in a copper vessel and simmer over low heat until reduced to five or six *dou*. Add four *dou* of white honey and continue simmering over a water bath, stirring constantly for several days until it can be formed into pills. Take one pill the size of a chicken egg thrice daily, or mix with wine. Effects appear within ten days.

Do not attempt to process all the rehmannia and asparagus at once; store excess in soil to prevent spoilage.

**Divine Formula for Longevity**
Peel three *hu* of asparagus root, thoroughly wash, pound, and extract one *hu* of juice. Simmer over low heat until reduced to about five *dou*, then add one *dou* of white honey. Roast sesame until fragrant and golden, grind into two *dou* of powder, and stir into the mixture without pause until thickened. Shape into cakes with soybean flour, three *cun* square and half a *cun* thick. Consume one cake daily. After a hundred days, the skin becomes lustrous, white hair turns black, fallen teeth regrow, and lifespan extends indefinitely. This method of consuming asparagus is most wondrous.

**Perfected One’s Asparagus Root Wine Formula**
Harvest the roots in autumn, thoroughly pound, and extract juice as desired. Soak rice and yeast in the juice to brew wine as usual. Alternatively, gather the roots, dry, grind into powder, and take a square-inch spoonful with this wine three to four times daily. Avoid excessive intoxication; no restrictions apply.

After three years of consuming the medicine, all illnesses are cured, and leprous worms bore through the skin, exiting from the joints. After three years, hair and fallen eyebrows regrow; after ten years, one’s name is inscribed in the Register of Life. After twenty years, one feels neither cold in winter nor heat in summer; after thirty years, an elder of a hundred years appears as a youth of fifteen. After forty years, one attains communion with spirits, and a divine maiden will bring medicine—upon consuming it, this is the divine elixir. Three days later, one sheds the mortal form and ascends as an immortal. Even after obtaining the divine cinnabar, drinking this wine further enhances its effects.

**Invigorating Immortal Wine Formula**
Take twenty *jin* each of *Atractylodes* (术) and rehmannia (地黄), and twenty *jin* of *Solanum* (五茄), removing the outer skin. Chop finely and boil in one *shi* and five *dou* of water until reduced to two *dou* of liquid. Strain and use the decoction to soak yeast, then brew with one *shi* of glutinous millet as in standard wine-making. Once the wine is ready, drink one cup thrice daily. After one month, the body becomes robust; after two months, the skin glows, and one can run as swiftly as a galloping horse, free from all ailments. For smaller batches, use two *dou* of rice or more as the standard, with four *jin* each of *Solanum* and rehmannia (using only the stems of *Solanum*).

**Divine Wine for Curing All Illnesses**
Take five *jin* each of hemp seeds and wheat yeast. Process the hemp seeds and yeast finely, sift, and soak together in one *shi* of water for three nights. Strain and discard the dregs, then steam five *dou* of glutinous millet and add to the liquid at an appropriate temperature. Let it ferment for two more nights before the medicine is ready. Consume as desired, but avoid letting the water grow cold, or the medicine will fail. Use only pure, fresh white rice. Consume this medicinal wine for a hundred days before practicing other Daoist methods.

**Numinous Treasure Wine of Rehmannia and Lycium**
Gather over a hundred *jin* of lycium roots and stems, wash to remove dirt, chop finely, and boil in a large cauldron with ample water until reduced to about five *dou* of liquid. Strain through silk to clarify. Take twenty *jin* of rehmannia roots, wash to remove soil, pound, and extract the juice. Pour about one *dou* of lycium decoction over the rehmannia dregs, press to extract all juice, then combine both juices. Take three *jin* of fine yeast, grind, and soak in the combined juice. Wash three *dou* of red glutinous millet, steam, and pour the rehmannia-lycium juice over it. Remove the yeast dregs once the millet is cooked, then ferment. Once the wine is ready, drink according to one’s capacity, stopping before intoxication. This wine cures wind-dampness, chronic cold, qi ascent, emaciation, and all ailments. To brighten the eyes, take a square-inch spoonful of *Kochia scoparia* (地肤) powder with this wine. Abstain from sexual activity, pork, raw fish, and *Veronica* vegetables. With prolonged consumption, one attains longevity and immortality.

**Asparagus Wine Formula**
Take thirty *jin* of asparagus, wash clean, and place in a silk bag. Use one *dou* of asparagus juice to soak the fermented rice, then brew with one *shi* of rice as usual. Add yeast and ferment according to standard methods. Place the bag of asparagus at the bottom of the vessel, add the rice, and seal with mud. After thirty days, the wine is ready; strain out the asparagus dregs and drink without becoming excessively intoxicated. Consuming one *hu* cures all illnesses and imparts a jade-like luster to the body. This wine may also be used to take asparagus pills, chrysanthemum, or cypress seeds, yielding excellent results. Another method states to remove the dregs after one month.

**Lycium Wine Formula**
Cures wind, the five taxations, the seven injuries, and strengthens bones. Take a hundred *jin* of lycium, chop finely (including stems), wash to remove soil, and boil. When the inner stem can be peeled, and the outer skin is dry, it is done. Strain and reserve the liquid, then boil the remaining raw lycium as before. For one *hu* of rice, use a hundred *jin* of lycium decoction, ensuring sufficient liquid to brew one *hu* of rice.

**Brewing Method**
Use refined glutinous or *Lin* rice, winnow thoroughly, and wipe clean with a damp cloth. Soak in lycium decoction, steam, and spread to cool. Soak the yeast in lycium liquid and proceed as in standard brewing. To make clear wine, add yeast starter. Another formula: brew with thirty *jin* of *Zanthoxylum* (猪椒) for superior results. Yet another: combine with thirty *jin* of rehmannia to nourish the marrow. Boil as with lycium and use to soak one *shi* of rice.

**Divine Wine Formula**
Take three *dou* of rice, three *jin* of yeast, and ten large aconite roots. Brew without adding water, using three *dou* of aged wine. Dry in the sun, then grind into powder. To make one *dou* of wine, take a square-inch spoonful of the powder and add to one *dou* of water; it will instantly become fine wine. Consume according to one’s capacity. Dry the wine and other medicines in the sun, then grind into powder for treating cold illnesses.

**Divine Wine Formula**
Take three *jin* of asparagus and one *dou* of rice, steam until cooked, and add just enough water to submerge the asparagus. Place in a bag and ferment. Once ready, combine and strain. Drink without becoming intoxicated, and avoid consuming vegetables or garlic. Consuming one *hu* of this wine cures all illnesses.

**Immortal’s Dry Wine Method**
Soak three *dou* of glutinous millet, three *dou* of non-glutinous rice, and two *dou* of malt in five *dou* of aged wine for five days. Remove, steam thoroughly without leakage, and dry in the shade for a hundred days, ensuring no loss of qi. Form into pieces the size of *bo* tiles; adding to two *dou* of water instantly produces wine. Use warm water in winter.

**Immortal’s Nourishing Green Millet Formula**
Take one *dou* of green millet, wash, and soak in aged wine for three days. Steam without leakage, then steam and sun-dry repeatedly, avoiding exposure to sunlight. Store carefully in a leather bag. When entering mountains or traveling far, one meal suffices for ten days without hunger. After ten days, another meal sustains for forty-nine days; after forty-nine days, another meal sustains for four hundred and ninety years as one cycle. One formula recommends *Xuan Liang* millet; another specifies three *dou*.

**Another Formula**
Take one *dou* of green millet and three *jin* of red halloysite. Combine, soak in water until sufficient, and place in a warm location for two to three days until a film forms. Pound into pills the size of plums. Consume three pills daily to eliminate hunger; drink water when thirsty. This enables travel of over a thousand *li* without hunger or thirst.

**Another Formula**
Take rice, wash thoroughly, steam and sun-dry repeatedly, then pound into powder. Consume once daily with water; after thirty days, drink a cup of water daily. This sustains one for life without hunger, enabling travel of three hundred *li* per day.

**Dry Wine Method**
Take five *dou* of refined rice and five *jin* of yeast. Soak in four *dou* of water until softened over two nights. Add two large *fuzi* (aconite) roots and two *liang* of fine cinnamon, then sift and mix into the wine. Press out the dregs, sun-dry, and return to the wine until all liquid is absorbed. Form into pills with white honey, the size of chicken eggs. Drop one pill into a *dou* of water to make fine wine.

**Powder of Japonica Rice for Consumption**
Take one *dou* of japonica rice and three *dou* of wine. Combine the two and soak until all wine is absorbed. Consume gradually; when thirsty, drink water. This suffices for thirty days, after which prepare again as before.

**Rice Formula for Consumption**
Take rice, wash thoroughly, steam repeatedly, sun-dry, and pound into powder. Consume once daily with water; after thirty days, drink a cup of water daily. This sustains one for life without hunger, enabling travel of three hundred *li* per day. If one wishes to eat, they may do so.

**Grain-Abstention Formula**
Take five *ge* each of japonica rice, broomcorn millet, wheat, soybeans, and hemp seeds. Roast the soybeans, then grind all into powder. Mix with one *jin* of white honey, boil to a hundred bubbles, then drop into cold water. Form into pills the size of plums. Consume one full dose in a single sitting to abstain from hunger for life. Prepare all ingredients separately, roasting only the soybeans.

**Le Zichang’s Date-Pit Sucking Method**
The Way of longevity lies in constantly holding a date pit in the mouth, moistening it with the milk-like saliva of an infant. Over time, when the mouth is full of fluid, swallow two-thirds and retain one-third, drawing it in with the breath. This is called "returning the essence." Repeat in cycles like a revolving wheel. When abstaining from grain, one may feel slight dizziness after five days, which soon passes. After fourteen days, dizziness recurs briefly, then subsides. After twenty-one days, the *qi* stabilizes. One may eat if desired or abstain naturally. During grain abstention, avoid sexual intercourse. One may consume a small amount of dried dates and drink no more than one *sheng* of wine. The method applies equally to men and women.
